utterances: You know, Nazis don't have the right to put up a sign next to the Holocaust Museum in Washington.
We would never accept the Japanese putting up a site next to Pearl Harbor.
There's no reason for us to accept a mosque next to the World Trade Center.
They rob these banks as ex-presidents, and they're all wearing masks.
Pollster Stan Greenberg worked for Bill Clinton in 1992, when third-party candidate Ross Perot roiled the race.
If it happened back then, Greenberg says, it can happen again.
I can't imagine that with 85 percent of the country thinking we're on the wrong track that there won't be a third-party candidate.
There has to be.
There's too much opportunity, too much anger with politics.
Former Republican Congressman Tom Davis agrees.
The message of the last three elections is clear: Voters are in an anti-incumbent, anti-Washington and now anti-Wall Street mood.
Davis says voters see the system as rigged.
They look at the political system as absolutely broken.
This is expressed by the fact that today the fastest growing element in the electorate are Independents.
Voters given the opportunity to cast a protest, sort of(ph) go a third way - I don't think it has been riper for that in probably a generation.
There already is an organization called Americans Elect trying to make sure voters get that opportunity.
Kahlil Byrd is its chief executive.
We are on the ballot in Florida, Michigan, Ohio, Nevada, and currently in California.
Officials are counting 1.6 million signatures and we expect to be on the ballot in California by mid-December.
Americans Elect is backed by wealthy investors and it will have the 20 to 30 million dollars it takes to get on the ballot in all 50 states.
Then, next June, it will hold an online convention where participants can draft an independent ticket for president.
Theoretically, anyone could emerge, but Americans Elect seems to be looking for fiscally conservative socially liberal candidates - think grand bargain instead of grand old party.
I wrote this third-party stump speech as I tried to try(ph) a model what an agenda like this might sound like.
That's columnist and former Clinton administration official Matt Miller.
He doesn't think either party is telling Americans the truth about what needs to be done to solve the country's problems.
He's a fan of Americans Elect, and he's drafted this pitch for what he hopes will be a radically centrist third-party candidate.
How's this for something different?

I want to raise your taxes, cut spending on programs you like, and force you to rethink how we run our schools, banks, armies, hospitals and elections, and I want you to cheer when I'm done, because if you embrace the decade of renewal I'm calling for...
A third-party candidate probably couldn't win the election, but in the past they've often had an impact on the race, particularly in a close race, as the early polling suggests 2012 will be.
Have a third party candidate on the ballot that helps the challenger.
That's Republican strategist Ed Rogers.
The last three races where there's been a prominent third candidate, the incumbent or his party lost.
In 1980, Jimmy Carter had John Andersen; in 1992, George H.W.
Bush had Ross Perot; and in 2000, Al Gore had Ralph Nader.
Rogers wishes the same for Barack Obama next year.
I wish somebody good and credible from the left would wander into the race and scramble the numbers in a few key states - Ohio, Wisconsin, Pennsylvania - for Obama.
Some sort of labor purist or eco-fanatic or something.
Yeah, I'd be for that.
I just don't think it's going to happen.
That's exactly what keeps Democrats up at night.
But Rogers worries about a challenge from the right - and it doesn't even have to be a national candidate.

As an example: An anti-immigration candidate with some organization and some money on the ballot in Colorado and Arizona and New Mexico - they've got three to five percent of the vote, you have Obama win with 46 percent or less.
You know, an angry Tea Party purist that just wants to rage against the machine - look out.
That could be real trouble.
But until an actual third-party ticket emerges, it's impossible for political professionals to game out who it would hurt â€“ President Obama or the Republican candidate.
Stan Greenberg...
Certainty there's going to be a third-party candidate.
And with absolute certainty, we have no idea what's going to happen.
Nothing about this election, Greenberg predicts, is going to follow a predictable path.
Mara Liasson, NPR News, Washington.
It's the holiday season and for some of us that means fruitcake.
Love it or hate it, at some point you've likely found yourself wondering who in the world makes fruitcakes.
What exactly is in them and how long will they really last?
Well, today we bring you answers.
The small town of Claxton, Georgia is the self-proclaimed Fruit Cake capitol of the world.
Two bakeries there make more than four million pounds a year of the holiday treat.
And NPR's Kathy Lohr visited both.
We actually begin with a blend of golden and natural raisins.
Dale Parker is vice president of Claxton Bakery, the larger of the town's two fruitcake companies.
A lot of folks ask us what are the little green things in fruitcake and that's simply candied pineapple.
There are also candied cherries, lemon and orange peel.
And, of course, nuts - almonds, walnuts and Georgia pecans.
(SOUNDBITE OF MACHINERY)
The family makes fruitcakes in relatively small batches, only 375 pounds at a time.
The candied fruit, nuts, and batter tumble together in a huge stainless steel barrel, rotating kind of like the way a cement mixer works.
You couldn't do that high speed, because if you did, then you'd pulverize the fruit.
The batter is so thick that workers level it in the pans by hand before the sheets go into a revolving oven.
The bakery goes back over a century, when an Italian immigrant, Savino Tos, moved from New York City to Georgia.
Dale Parker's father, Albert, worked in the bakery as a young boy and eventually bought the business.
Back then, fruitcakes were a delicacy at a time when many couldn't afford to buy fresh fruits and nuts.
Fruitcakes are often mocked.
Most famously, former ""Tonight Show"" host Johnny Carson contended there is just one fruitcake and that it gets re-gifted as people send it house to house every year.
As you might imagine, people in Claxton don't think it's funny.
Yeah, he said that, but he would not come locally and make that statement.
He'd only say it on TV.
Over the next 18 years, while Bernanke was building a career as a distinguished economics professor at Princeton, Greenspan was making his rep as a crisis manager.
He worked with Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin to bail out Mexico in 1994.
Four years later, he came to the rescue of world markets when Asia, Russia and Brazil turned into falling financial dominoes.
And when the dot-com bubble burst in 2001, he came to the rescue again.
Whatever his failures, including his endorsement of the 2001 tax cuts, Greenspan knew how to manage the world's financial crises.
He was good at letting the world's financial markets sleep soundly at night.
Bernanke might have to be even better.
Our government now spends more on wars, hurricanes and tax cuts than it brings in.
And foreigners, in particular the governments of China and Japan, are lending us the money to do it.
But what happens when these foreign lenders decide they're putting too many eggs in our basket?
The result could be higher interest rates, falling stock and home prices, a recession and perhaps the failure of some banks, the mother of all financial crises.
Right now, the talk is about Bernanke's theoretical writings on monetary policy.
He's a leading exponent of the theory that the Fed should announce how much inflation it's willing to tolerate and then put its policies on autopilot to reach that target.
But the responsibilities of being Fed chairman will turn the most devout theoretician into a pragmatist in short order.
Ask Alan Greenspan.
A financial panic sometimes means raising rates, sometimes lowering them, sometimes cooperating with other countries, sometimes confronting them.
The textbooks don't say much about that.
Bernanke's ability to live up to this challenge one day may well define his tenure as Fed chairman.
It's one thing to know when to take away the punch bowl.
It's another to know what to do when the party breaks into a brawl.
Commentator Ev Ehrlich is president of the ESC Company, which is an economics consulting firm here in Washington.
Now, the war in Iraq through the eyes of Laith Kubba.
He was a longtime Iraqi exile who went back to Baghdad to try to help build a Democratic and transparent government.
He has since returned to Washington disillusioned and worried about the violence tearing his country apart.
NPR's Michele Kelemen reports.
In his spartan office at the National Endowment for Democracy, Laith Kubba keeps no pictures or visible mementos from his ten-month stint in Iraq.
He describes the situation in Iraq after the ouster of Saddam Hussein as a huge letdown.
The question he hates most is was it worth it?
I don't think there has ever been a doubt in my mind that we need to get rid of Saddam Hussein, but I tell people don't make it either Saddam Hussein or this mess, because there is a lot in between.
He said the mess was not the consequence of forcing Saddam Hussein out of power but of poor planning for the day after.
Laith Kubba should know about that.
Over a decade ago, he helped form a powerful umbrella group of Iraqi exiles with his second cousin, Ahmed Chalabi.
But unlike Chalabi, who became the golden boy of the Pentagon, Kubba had a more cautious approach to Iraq in the run up to this war.
He worked with the State Department on its post war plans, which were eventually shelved.
Kubba remembers only once getting an invitation to a high level meeting at the Pentagon.
I was (unintelligible), I think by another three or four other people, experts on Iraq, I haven't met before.
And just before the meeting started, by about many five minutes, I was called out of the meeting and I was asked to leave the room.
Yeah, just not to be in that meeting.
And to me that was like a joke.
A joke that came to epitomize the view that the Pentagon just wanted to hear the war would be easy.
After Saddam was toppled, and after a new government was elected, Kubba ended nearly 30 years in exile and went back to Baghdad to find his family home in ruins.
It had been seized by Saddam's regime while the family was abroad.
My sister refused to look at, categorically refused to look at the family home, even in pictures, because she just wanted to keep the good memories of the past.
My brother, who looked at it, just couldn't hold on.
I mean, he cried.

But the family home was the least of Kubba's troubles, and besides, when he decided to join the government as a spokesman for Prime Minister Ibrahim Jaafari, he lived in the relative security of Baghdad's green zone.
He would venture out mainly to comfort Iraqis in the wake of car bombings and other attacks.
He found himself watching Iraq descend into chaos with a government unable to stop it.
I was very frustrated seeing an ineffective government in Iraq, and I know Iraqis can do much, much better than that.
What was holding back the way the system was designed, as if somebody gave you a jacket, it's just designed the wrong way, and you have to force yourself to fit into the jacket, which restrains you.
It doesn't protect you.
It doesn't make you look pretty.
Laith Kubba says there's enough blame to go around.
He says the U.S.
made a mistake when it disbanded the army when it occupied Iraq.
And then, he says, international advisors were wrong to set up a proportional voting system, which Kubba believes only highlighted the ethnic and religious divisions in the country.
He comes from a mixed marriage, a Shiite father and a Sunni mother, and always hoped to see a secular democracy in Iraq.
But when he tried his hand at politics, running with other moderates, he failed.
Currently, people like myself have no room to serve in the country.
I think we've been squeezed out.
Currently, we have just groups that want to fight, and the bounty is big.
It's billions of oil money.
